abstract.text: A Uniform Resource Locator (URL) is a universal identifier,
which often describes the location of a resource.

inlineContent.text: Construct a
from a URL string:
WebURL conforms to the
, which specifies how browsers and other actors
on the web platform interpret URLs. The parser is very forgiving, so it has great compatibility with
real-world URLs. It also supports a number of modern features, such as Unicode domain names (IDNA).
WebURL values are entirely defined by their string representation (their
serialization
); at any time,
you can convert a URL to a string and back (for example, encoding to JSON) and the result will be an identical URL.
To obtain a URL‚Äôs serialization, call the
function
or simply construct a
URLs have structure; they can be split in to components such as a
, and
The scheme identifies the kind of URL, and determines how other components should be interpreted.

code: scheme  username     hostname    port      path                 query           fragment

inlineContent.text: You can read and write a component‚Äôs string value using its respective property.
The documentation page for each property contains more information about its corresponding URL component.
Just as URLs have structure, some components can have
their own
internal structure;
notably, the path is usually a list of segments (
), and a popular convention
is to write a list of key-value pairs in the URL‚Äôs query (
WebURL takes advantage of Swift language features such as enumerations with associated values
and write-through views to offer more expressive APIs than is possible with flat component strings.
is an enum, explaining how the standard interprets the URL‚Äôs hostname.
Not only can it help libraries understand precisely which
kind of host
is expressed by the URL,
it includes the actual network address value which can be used to establish a connection.
is a
view, containing the segments in the URL‚Äôs path.
It comes with a full complement of APIs to add, remove, or replace any part of the path, and transparently
handles details such as percent-encoding.
(Demonstrated below)
is also a view, containing the key-value pairs in the URL‚Äôs query.
Getting and setting values is simple - just access a key as if it were the name of a property,
or insert whole groups of values using dictionaries.
(Demonstrated below)
is a view of the URL‚Äôs path segments as a
It has a comprehensive, familiar API - including
loops, slices, and generic algorithms such as
and
. It transparently handles percent-encoding, so you can process paths naturally.

Together they offer a powerful set of tools, available at any time simply by accessing

inlineContent.text: In the previous example, we used
to add a key-value pair to the URL‚Äôs query component.
is another write-through view, and it makes use of Swift‚Äôs dynamic-member syntax to access
key-value pairs as though they were properties.

inlineContent.text: Another feature of WebURL is that it is always normalized - every component is simplified according to the standard.
For example, URL scheme names and some hostnames are normalized to lowercase, and paths containing
segments
are automatically compacted. There is no
or
function, so you‚Äôll never forget to call it.
This makes processing URLs simpler and more robust - both for your code, and other systems who later process the URL.
To ensure you can actually use WebURL today, the package includes a number of integration libraries
for popular first-party and third-party libraries.
integrates with
swift-system
(and
System.framework
on Apple platforms) to offer
conversions between
and
. It‚Äôs the best way to work with file URLs.
integrates with
Foundation
so you can convert between
and
and use Foundation APIs such as
with WebURL. We recommend reading
for a discussion of how to safely work with multiple URL standards.
